member.name: T:ActiproSoftware.Products.Editors.SR
member.summary: Provides access to the string resources of this assembly, also allowing for their customization.
member.remarks:
Call the method to return a resolved resource string. If a custom string has been set for a specified string resource name, it will be returned. Otherwise, the default string resource value is returned.
If any of the resource strings are customized via a call to , it is best to do so before any other classes in this assembly are referenced, such as in the application startup.

member.param: The name of the resource for which to search.
member.returns: true if a custom string is defined for the specified string resource; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers
member.summary: Specifies the triggers that force a -derived control to immediately commit any changes.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers.None
member.summary: Indicates that changes will only be committed when the part loses focus or the user pressed the Enter key.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers.SpinnerChange
member.summary: Indicates that changes made using an associated Spinner control will be committed immediately. Other changes will only be committed when the part loses focus.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers.StringValueChange
member.summary: Indicates that changes made by typing will be committed immediately. Other changes will only be committed when the part loses focus.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers.EnterKeyDown
member.summary: Indicates that changes made will be committed when the Enter key is pressed.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers.SpinnerChangeOrEnterKeyDown
member.summary: Indicates that changes made using an associated Spinner control will be committed immediately. Other changes will only be committed when the part loses focus or the user pressed the Enter key.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.PartValueCommitTriggers.All
member.summary: Indicates that changes will be always be committed immediately.

member.name: T:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.Primitives.SyncBinding
member.summary: Represents a two-way binding markup extension.
member.remarks: This binding functions much like the standard WPF (using a Mode of TwoWay), but does a better job of keeping two properties synchronized. Typically with a two-way Binding coerced values are not always pushed back to the target property. With this class, coerced values are pushed back to the target property.

member.name: T:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.SpinBehavior
member.summary: Specifies the various behaviors supported when spinning a value in a PartEditBox.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.SpinBehavior.NoWrap
member.summary: Indicates that the values will not wrap when the minimum or maximum are reached.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.SpinBehavior.SimpleWrap
member.summary: Indicates that the values will wrap when the minimum or maximum are reached (e.g. incrementing the maximum value will result in the minimum value).
member.remarks: Some types can support more advanced wrapping behaviors, such as DateTime. For example, if you increment the minute part of the time "4:59 pm", then there are three possible outcomes: 1. "4:59pm" - This is equivalent to the NoWrap option. 2. "4:00pm" - This is equivalent to the SimpleWrap option. 3. "5:00pm" - This is equivalent to the Wrap option, which affects the hour part.

member.name: F:ActiproSoftware.Windows.Controls.Editors.SpinBehavior.Wrap
member.summary: Indicates that the values will wrap when the minimum or maximum are reached (e.g. incrementing the maximum value will result in the minimum value), but may or may not include special handling (see remarks for more information).
member.remarks: Some types can support more advanced wrapping behaviors, such as DateTime. For example, if you increment the minute part of the time "4:59 pm", then there are three possible outcomes: 1. "4:59pm" - This is equivalent to the NoWrap option. 2. "4:00pm" - This is equivalent to the SimpleWrap option. 3. "5:00pm" - This is equivalent to the Wrap option, which affects the hour part.
